title: You’re Probably Washing Your Face WrongYou’re Probably Washing Your Face Wrong
text:
MY 94-YEAR-OLD grandmother has only ever washed her face with warm water or, when she’s feeling fancy, the original Noxzema cold cream, which she’ll scoop out of the blue tub with her fingers, apply in a thick layer, and then gingerly tissue off. Her skin is luminous. But most dermatologists would likely cringe at her technique. While face-washing seems like it should be one of our more mindless beauty exercises—wash, rinse, move on—as we’ve become more obsessive about our skin care regimens, it has taken on greater importance. And, under this new scrutiny, the question has arisen: Are we doing it wrong?

Which is to say overdoing it. The fixation on cleanliness ingrained in us early on may be to blame for our collective desire for immaculate skin. “[Squeaky clean] is not a sign of skin health…our obsession with that feeling is disrupting and destroying our skin’s barrier,” said Dr. Whitney Bowe, a New York City dermatologist and author of “Dirty Looks.”

TAKE ME TO THE CLEANERS

Our picks in seven categories of wash warfare

Balm

BASIC Banila Co. Cleansing Balm, $19, sokoglam.com ALTERNATIVE Versed Cleanser, $18, target.com LUXE Cleansing Balm, $110, omorovicza.com Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal

Exfoliate

BASIC Bia Face Wash, $45, codexbeauty.com; ALTERNATIVE Face Wash, $42, philosophy.com; LUXE Face Wash, $48, reflektskincare.com Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal

When that delicate protective barrier is compromised, skin can feel dehydrated, reactive and experience inflammatory conditions like acne. While overwashing can be the culprit, so can washing with products that are too harsh. The acid mantle of a healthy complexion (the film on the skin’s surface) has a pH of around 4 to 5.5, and an ideal cleanser should have a similar pH level. That’s why Emily Parr, co-founder of HoliFrog, a new line of facial cleansers, chose to list the pH level of all the products on their labels.

Cleansing is always the first skin care step, which underlines its importance. “It can set the tone for the rest of your routine,” said Alicia Yoon, founder of skin care line Peach & Lily. “If skin isn’t cleansed well…other products may not absorb as effectively, and if a cleanser is too harsh... skin faces an uphill battle.” When considering cleansers, it helps to observe some parameters—choose a foaming product for oilier skin, a milky or gel-based one for dry skin, an oil or balm if you’re a makeup lover. These are not, however, hard and fast rules; more crucial is how a product makes your skin feel. “When we cleanse, our skin should feel hydrated, smooth and nourished, not tight,” said Dr. Bowe.

Foam

BASIC Face Wash, $15, laroche-posay.us; ALTERNATIVE Face Wash, $25, oneloveorganics.com; LUXE Face Wash, $45, ernolaszlo.com Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal

Gel

BASIC Cosrx Face Wash, $12, sokoglam.com; ALTERNATIVE Face Wash, $28, peachandlily.com; LUXE Face Wash, $76, tataharperskincare.com Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal

Method also matters. Ms. Yoon advocates the double cleanse, a staple in Korean skin care: First use an oil-based cleanser to dissolve makeup and oily impurities; follow with a water-based cleanser to address sweat, dirt and water-based impurities. For her part, Dr. Bowe isn’t convinced that arduous and potentially drying double cleansing is for everyone. She thinks frequent users of heavy makeup could benefit from it, and she might urge women who live in particularly polluted cities to consider it a few nights a week.

San Francisco facialist Kristina Holey may not think a double cleanse is essential, but she does see a benefit to spending extra time on the process. “You can use cleansing as an excuse to massage and stimulate circulation and drainage in the face,” said Ms. Holey, who likes to make small circles with varying pressure over the neck and entire face.

Micellar

BASIC Bioderma Micellar Water, $15, walgreens.com; ALTERNATIVE Micellar Water, $26, nuriabeauty.com; LUXE Son & Park Cleansing Water, $30, sokoglam.com Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal

Milky

BASIC Face Wash, $38, holifrog.com; ALTERNATIVE Face Wash, $18, glossier.com; LUXE Biologique Recherche Face Wash, $67, Daphne Studio, 347-382-8807 Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal

When it comes to a cleanser with more active ingredients (like alpha hydroxyl acids), New York dermatologist Dr. Joshua Zeichner tells his patients to keep it on their faces long enough to recite the alphabet, then rinse. To rinse, use lukewarm water (never hot; too drying), then gently pat the skin until it’s not completely dry (products are best applied to a moist surface).

The most important cleansing advice may be this: “Listen to your skin,” counseled Ms. Yoon. And if it sometimes wants nothing but water, Ms. Holey, for one, doesn’t think that’s such a bad idea. “The skin renews itself, so getting in its way too much can be more detrimental than beneficial over time,” she added. An idea my grandmother could certainly get behind.

Oil

BASIC Kristina Holey & Marie Veronique Cleansing Oil, $40, marieveronique.com; ALTERNATIVE Cleansing Oil, $49, beautycounter.com; LUXE Cleansing Oil, $48, tatcha.com Photo: F. Martin Ramin/The Wall Street Journal

description: As our skin-care routines grow ever more elaborate, here’s the latest in cleansing wisdom from dermatologists and facialists.
